questions.question: When your friend group can't decide where to eat dinner, you typically:

answers.text: Suggest we vote and go with majority preference
Ask everyone's preferences and find a compromise
Offer a strong suggestion and rally people around it
Just pick a place and tell everyone to meet you there

questions.fact: George Washington's famous wooden teeth are a myth — his dentures were actually made from hippopotamus ivory, human teeth, and metal springs.

questions.question: At work, when facing a difficult decision with your team:

answers.text: Schedule a meeting to hear everyone's input first
Make the call quickly based on your judgment
Delegate the decision to whoever is most affected
Gather opinions but ultimately trust your own instinct

questions.fact: Thomas Jefferson kept a pet mockingbird named Dick in his White House study that would fly around the room, perch on his shoulder, and take treats from his lips.

questions.question: When leading a project with a tight deadline:

answers.text: Break into tasks and let team members own their pieces
Take charge and direct everyone's specific actions
Set clear goals and let people find their own path
Make quick calls without much discussion to save time

questions.fact: Abraham Lincoln kept important documents tucked inside his iconic stovepipe hat, using it as a portable filing cabinet.

questions.question: When considering a major life change (new job, moving cities):

answers.text: Research extensively and make pro/con lists for months
Trust your gut and jump in if it feels right
Test the waters first with small steps
Go all-in once you've made up your mind

questions.fact: Theodore Roosevelt went completely blind in his left eye after a boxing match in the White House, but kept it secret from the public for years.
questions.factSources: Constitution Center | American Academy of Ophthalmology

questions.question: Your approach to trying new experiences:

answers.text: Prefer familiar activities you know you'll enjoy
Always excited to try something you've never done
Will try new things if someone else suggests it
Actively seek out adventurous or unconventional experiences

questions.fact: Franklin D. Roosevelt and his wife Eleanor were fifth cousins once removed, and Teddy Roosevelt (Eleanor's uncle) gave away the bride at their wedding.

questions.question: When faced with a financial opportunity that could pay off big or fail:

answers.text: Pass unless you can afford to lose the money
Calculate odds carefully before deciding
Take the chance if potential reward excites you
Go for it — fortune favors the brave

questions.fact: Ronald Reagan co-starred with a chimpanzee in the 1951 film "Bedtime for Bonzo." During filming, the chimp grabbed his necktie and nearly strangled him before crew members cut him free.

questions.question: At a party with mostly strangers:

answers.text: Stick with the few people you know
Work the room and introduce yourself to everyone
Have a few deep conversations with interesting people
Become the life of the party with stories and jokes

questions.fact: Bill Clinton is an accomplished saxophone player who won first chair in Arkansas's All-State Band and seriously considered pursuing a career in music before entering politics.
questions.factSources: Classic FM | The Metropolitan Museum of Art

questions.question: After a long, stressful week, you recharge by:

answers.text: Spending quiet time alone or with one close friend
Going out with a group of friends
Doing a solo activity like reading or hiking
Hosting people or attending social events

questions.fact: George W. Bush was a part-owner of the Texas Rangers baseball team from 1989 to 1998, serving as managing general partner and often sitting in the stands as a regular fan.

questions.question: When meeting new people, you typically:

answers.text: Let them do most of the talking at first
Take the lead in conversation and share about yourself
Keep things polite but surface-level
Quickly build rapport and make them feel comfortable

questions.fact: Barack Obama collects Spider-Man and Conan the Barbarian comic books and has said reading comics as a child inspired his interest in storytelling.

questions.question: When your values conflict with what's practical:

answers.text: Stick to your principles even if it's harder
Find a middle ground that's good enough
Do what works and revisit values later
Never compromise on core beliefs

questions.fact: Donald Trump received a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame in 2007 for his work as producer of the Miss Universe pageants and "The Apprentice."
questions.factSources: Hollywood Walk of Fame | Fast Company

questions.question: Your approach to rules and guidelines:

answers.text: Rules exist for good reasons and should be followed
Rules are guidelines — bend them when it makes sense
Some rules are important, others are suggestions
Consistency and fairness matter more than convenience

questions.fact: George Washington was an avid breeder who created the American Foxhound by crossing French hounds with English foxhounds.

questions.question: When working toward a goal, if circumstances change:

answers.text: Adapt your approach while keeping the end goal
Stick to your original plan — you chose it for a reason
Completely pivot if a better opportunity appears
Stay true to your vision even if the path is harder

questions.fact: Thomas Jefferson designed his own tombstone and wrote his own epitaph — notably leaving out that he had been President of the United States.

questions.question: When someone asks your opinion on their clearly bad idea:

answers.text: Point out the flaws directly but constructively
Find something positive to say while gently steering them away
Tell them straight up it won't work
Ask questions to help them realize the issues themselves

questions.fact: Abraham Lincoln was a licensed bartender and co-owned a tavern called "Berry and Lincoln" in New Salem, Illinois before entering politics.

questions.question: Your typical communication style in disagreements:

answers.text: Say exactly what you think without sugarcoating
Choose words carefully to avoid offense
Be honest but soften the message
Speak bluntly — people appreciate directness

questions.fact: Theodore Roosevelt read at least one book every single day — often finishing two or three — and could speed-read entire pages at a glance.

questions.question: When giving feedback to someone:

answers.text: Be straightforward about what needs to improve
Lead with positives before mentioning concerns
Use tact and framing to deliver difficult messages
Cut to the chase — clarity over comfort

questions.fact: Franklin D. Roosevelt used a secret train platform beneath the Waldorf Astoria hotel in New York to enter and exit without being seen in his wheelchair.
